what: Compute standard deviation of Beta distribution. — beta_sd
title: Compute standard deviation of Beta distribution. — beta_sd
text: Compute standard deviation Beta distribution.

title: Compute standard deviation of Beta distribution. — beta_sd
Compute standard deviation of Beta distribution. — beta_sd
text: alpha, beta Integers. Need greater zero. Control shape distribution. alpha = 4, beta = 4 gives bell-shaped distribution alpha = 1, beta = 1 gives Uniform distribution. alpha = 0.5, beta = 0.5 gives high-variance distribution low high values likely. , b Integers. Lower upper bound unit-level causal effects.

title: Compute standard deviation of Beta distribution. — beta_sd
text: integer.

title: Compute standard deviation of Beta distribution. — beta_sd
text: Assuming unit-level causal effects vary b, function computes implied standard deviations distribution causal effects, assuming Beta distribution parameters alpha beta. computed standard deviation can used inform magnitude sensitivity parameter sigma post_instrument_bounds().

title: Compute standard deviation of Beta distribution. — beta_sd
text: Schuessler, J., Glynn, . N., & Rueda, M.R. (2023). Post-Instrument Bias.

title: Compute standard deviation of Beta distribution. — beta_sd
code: x <- seq(0, 1, length.out = 100) plot(x, dbeta(x, shape1 = 1, shape2 = 1), type = "l", ylim = c(0, 3.5), xlab = expression(paste(gamma[i])), ylab = "Density") lines(x, dbeta(x, shape1 = 0.5, shape2 = 0.5), type = "l",      lty = "dashed") lines(x, dbeta(x, shape1 = 4, shape2 = 4), type = "l",      lty = "dotted") legend(x = "top", c("Low Variance", "Medium Variance", "High Variance"),       lty = c("dotted", "solid", "dashed"))   beta_sd(alpha = 1, beta = 1, a= 0, b = 1) # medium variance #> [1] 0.2886751 beta_sd(alpha = 0.5, beta = 0.5, a = 0, b = 1) # high variance #> [1] 0.3535534 beta_sd(alpha = 4, beta = 4, a = 0, b = 1) # low variance #> [1] 0.1666667

what: Estimate components for sensitivity analysis. — estimate_sensitivity
title: Estimate components for sensitivity analysis. — estimate_sensitivity
text: Estimate components sensitivity analysis.

title: Estimate components for sensitivity analysis. — estimate_sensitivity
code: estimate_sensitivity(   df,   R = 1501,   outcome,   treat,   inst,   post.inst,   x = NULL,   fe = NULL,   weights = NULL,   seed,   parallel = "no",   ncpus = getOption("boot.ncpus", 1L),   cl = NULL )

title: Estimate components for sensitivity analysis. — estimate_sensitivity
text: df Data frame R Number bootstrap replications outcome Name dependent variables interest Y, string treat Name treatment interest D, string inst Name instrument Z, string post.inst Name post-instrument variable M, string x Names controls, string vector strings fe Names variables passed fixed effects (factors), string vector strings weights Vector weights used regressions seed Seed make bootstrap analysis replicable. Must set number parallel One c("", "snow", "multicore") parallelize bootstrap. Default "". ncpus Integer: number processes used parallel operation cl optional parallel snow cluster use parallel = "snow".

title: Estimate components for sensitivity analysis. — estimate_sensitivity
text: object class boot, t0 contains point estimates elements bounds estimator, t contains R bootstrap replicates thereof.

title: Estimate components for sensitivity analysis. — estimate_sensitivity
text: Schuessler, J., Glynn, . N., & Rueda, M.R. (2023). Post-Instrument Bias. Glynn, . N., Rueda, M. R., & Schuessler, J. (2023). Post-Instrument Bias Linear Models. Sociological Methods & Research.

title: Estimate components for sensitivity analysis. — estimate_sensitivity
code: if (FALSE) { data(carnegie_marinov) y <- "new_empinxavg" m <- "pwt_openk" d <- "EV" z <- "l2CPcol2" fe <- c("ccode", "year") out <- estimate_sensitivity(carnegie_marinov, R = 1501,                      outcome = y, treat = d, inst = z, post.inst = m,                      fe = fe,                      seed = 823,                      parallel = "snow",                      ncpus = 4)                       }

text: Plot estimated bounds sensitivity analysis respect post-instrument covariates.

title: Plot estimated bounds for sensitivity analysis with respect to post-instrument covariates. — plot_pib_bounds
code: plot_pib_bounds(   bounds,   whichCI = "percentile",   annotate.sigma = "minmax",   digits = 2,   set.ylim = T,   set.xlim = T,   ylab = "Effect Estimate",   xlab = expression(paste("E[", gamma[i], "]")),   ylim = NULL,   xlim = NULL,   lty = "dashed",   ... )

title: Plot estimated bounds for sensitivity analysis with respect to post-instrument covariates. — plot_pib_bounds
text: bounds object post.instrument.bounds() whichCI Determines type boostrap confidence interval plotted. Either "percentile" (default) "basic" annotate.sigma confidence intervals annotated values sigma? Default "minmax" (annotating CI lowest highest values sigma). Alternatives can "none" "" digits annotating sigma, controls rounding annotated values. Default 2. set.ylim Logical. limit Y-axis automatically determined? FALSE, argument ylim set. Default TRUE set.xlim Logical. limit X-axis automatically determined? FALSE, argument xlim set. Default TRUE ylab, xlab, ... Label Y- X-axis, graphical parameters. xlim, ylim set.ylim = F set.ylim = F, sets limits axes. horizontal.lty Controls appearance horizontal line 0. Default "dashed".

what: Compute bounds from estimated components. — post_instrument_bounds
title: Compute bounds from estimated components. — post_instrument_bounds
text: Compute bounds estimated components.

title: Compute bounds from estimated components. — post_instrument_bounds
code: post_instrument_bounds(   gamma,   sigma = 0,   n.sigma = 5,   estimates,   df,   outcome,   post.inst,   whichCI = "percentile",   remove.outliers = T,   conf = 0.95 )

title: Compute bounds from estimated components. — post_instrument_bounds
text: gamma Integer vector integers giving lowest highest value mean causal effect post-instrument variable M outcome Y sigma Integer vector integers giving lowest highest value variance causal effect M Y. Must non-negative. Defaults zero. n.sigma Integer: Number distinct values sigma (within bounds provided sigma argument) compute bounds. Defaults 5. estimates object calling estimate_sensitivity() contains vector point estimates t well bootstrap replicates t0 df Data frame outcome Name dependent variables interest Y, string post.inst Name post-instrument variable M, string whichCI Determines type boostrap confidence interval: percentile (default), basic, remove.outliers Logical. TRUE (default), outliers bootstrapped sampling distribution 2SLS regressions Y M removed. resulting sampling distribution better approximate results standard robust standard errors. conf confidence level confidence intervals. Defaults 0.95

title: Compute bounds from estimated components. — post_instrument_bounds
text: matrix values gamma, sigma, point estimates bounds treatment effect, confidence intervals point estimates bounds.

title: Compute bounds from estimated components. — post_instrument_bounds
text: function assumes instrument Z, treatment D, post-instrument variable M binary (case sensitivity parameter gamma sigma can left default value zero), z binary D M continuous, case gamma sigma sensitivity parameters.

title: Compute bounds from estimated components. — post_instrument_bounds
text: Schuessler, J., Glynn, . N., & Rueda, M.R. (2023). Post-Instrument Bias. Glynn, . N., Rueda, M. R., & Schuessler, J. (2023). Post-Instrument Bias Linear Models. Sociological Methods & Research.

title: Compute bounds from estimated components. — post_instrument_bounds
code: if (FALSE) { gamma <- c(-0.02, 0.02) sigma <- c(0, 0.002) bounds <- post.instrument.bounds(gamma = gamma, sigma = sigma, n.sigma = 2, estimates = out)}
